x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: After a disaster, survivors face a long, complex recovery process. They must navigate multiple disconnected systems to apply for aid, mental health services, insurance claims, and housing support. Paper forms, fragmented platforms, and unclear guidance lead to confusion, delays, and missed opportunities—especially for underserved communities. At the same time, governments and nonprofits lack real-time data on recovery progress, making it difficult to allocate resources effectively.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

We propose a ServiceNow-powered Community Recovery Hub:

Unified Recovery Portal: Citizens apply for multiple services (financial aid, housing repair, insurance claims, counseling) through a guided experience.

AI-Powered Assistant: Uses GenAI to answer questions, recommend programs, and help fill out forms.

Document Intelligence: Extracts and validates data from uploaded ID, proof of residence, and insurance forms.

Smart Routing and Case Management: Auto-assigns cases to relevant agencies and tracks their progress.

Mental Health & Social Services Referrals: Connects users to counseling, support groups, and job assistance.

Recovery Analytics Dashboard: Visualizes recovery trends, bottlenecks, and equity gaps for policy-makers.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Integration with insurance, housing, and public assistance systems

AI/NLP support for document extraction and language understanding

Compliance with data privacy laws (e.g., HIPAA, GDPR)

Role-based access for case workers, agencies, and NGOs

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Data privacy and secure access to sensitive citizen information

Integrating with legacy aid and claims systems

Reaching low-income or rural populations with limited digital access

Managing inter-agency collaboration effectively

Training case workers and support staff on new systems
